Check AutoMod Status.short: Checks whether AutoMod would flag the specified message for review.
Check AutoMod Status.long:
Checks whether AutoMod would flag the specified message for review.
AutoMod is a moderation tool that holds inappropriate or harassing chat messages for moderators to review. Moderators approve or deny the messages that AutoMod flags; only approved messages are released to chat. AutoMod detects misspellings and evasive language automatically. For information about AutoMod, see [How to Use AutoMod](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/how-to-use-automod).
*Rate Limits*: Rates are limited per channel based on the account type rather than per access token.
Account type Limit per minute Limit per hour Normal 5 50 Affiliate 10 100 Partner 30 300
The above limits are in addition to the standard [Twitch API rate limits](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#twitch-rate-limits). The rate limit headers in the response represent the Twitch rate limits and not the above limits.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose AutoMod settings and list of blocked terms are used to check the message. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

data.description: The list of messages to check. The list must contain at least one message and may contain up to a maximum of 100 messages.

msg_id.description: A caller-defined ID used to correlate this message with the same message in the response.
possible: efined ID used to correlate this message with the same message in the response.

data.description: The list of messages and whether Twitch would approve them for chat.

msg_id.description: The caller-defined ID passed in the request.
possible: efined ID passed in the request.

is_permitted.description: A Boolean value that indicates whether Twitch would approve the message for chat or hold it for moderator review or block it from chat. Is *true* if Twitch would approve the message; otherwise, *false* if Twitch would hold the message for moderator review or block it from chat.

codes.200: Successfully checked the messages.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The `data` field is required and the list must contain one or more messages to check.
- The `msg_id` field is required.
- The `msg_text` field is required.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderation:read scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: - The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
codes.429: - The broadcaster exceeded the number of chat message checks that they may make. See the endpoint's rate limits.

Check AutoMod Status.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderation:read`

Manage Held AutoMod Messages.short: Allow or deny the message that AutoMod flagged for review.
Manage Held AutoMod Messages.long:
Allow or deny the message that AutoMod flagged for review. For information about AutoMod, see [How to Use AutoMod](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/how-to-use-automod).
To get messages that AutoMod is holding for review, subscribe to the *automod-queue.<moderator_id>.<channel_id>* [topic](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/pubsub#topics) using [PubSub](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/pubsub). PubSub sends a notification to your app when AutoMod holds a message for review.

user_id.description: The moderator who is approving or denying the held message. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

msg_id.description: The ID of the message to allow or deny.

action.description:
The action to take for the message. Possible values are:
- ALLOW
- DENY

codes.204: Successfully approved or denied the message.
codes.400:
- The value in the `action` field is not valid.
- The `user_id` field is required.
- The `msg_id` field is required.
- The `action` field is required.
codes.401:
- The ID in `user_id` must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:manage:automod scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: - The user in user_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.
codes.404: - The message specified in the `msg_id` field was not found.

Manage Held AutoMod Messages.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:manage:automod`

broadcaster_id.description: The broadcaster’s ID.

moderator_id.description: The moderator’s ID.

overall_level.description: The default AutoMod level for the broadcaster. This field is *null* if the broadcaster has set one or more of the individual settings.

bullying.description: The Automod level for hostility involving name calling or insults.

race_ethnicity_or_religion.description: The Automod level for racial discrimination.

sex_based_terms.description: The Automod level for sexual content.

codes.403: - The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.

aggression.description: The Automod level for hostility involving aggression.

bullying.description: The Automod level for hostility involving name calling or insults.

disability.description: The Automod level for discrimination against disability.

misogyny.description: The Automod level for discrimination against women.

data.description: The list of AutoMod settings. The list contains a single object that contains all the AutoMod settings.

broadcaster_id.description: The broadcaster’s ID.

moderator_id.description: The moderator’s ID.

overall_level.description: The default AutoMod level for the broadcaster. This field is *null* if the broadcaster has set one or more of the individual settings.

disability.description: The Automod level for discrimination against disability.

aggression.description: The Automod level for hostility involving aggression.

sexuality_sex_or_gender.description: The AutoMod level for discrimination based on sexuality, sex, or gender.

codes.200: Successfully updated the broadcaster’s AutoMod settings.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id is required.
- The moderator_id is required.
- The `overall_level` setting or one or more individual settings like `aggression` is required; the overall and individual settings are mutually exclusive, so don't set both.
- The value of one or more AutoMod settings is not valid.
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the user access token.

Update AutoMod Settings.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:manage:automod_settings`
Update AutoMod Settings.reqBodyInfo:
Because PUT is an overwrite operation, you must include all the fields that you want set after the operation completes. Typically, you’ll send a GET request, update the fields you want to change, and pass that object in the PUT request.
You may set either `overall_level` or the individual settings like `aggression`, but not both.
Setting `overall_level` applies default values to the individual settings. However, setting `overall_level` to 4 does not necessarily mean that it applies 4 to all the individual settings. Instead, it applies a set of recommended defaults to the rest of the settings. For example, if you set `overall_level` to 2, Twitch provides some filtering on discrimination and sexual content, but more filtering on hostility (see the first example response).
If `overall_level` is currently set and you update `swearing` to 3, `overall_level` will be set to *null* and all settings other than `swearing` will be set to 0. The same is true if individual settings are set and you update `overall_level` to 3 — all the individual settings are updated to reflect the default level.
Note that if you set all the individual settings to values that match what `overall_level` would have set them to, Twitch changes AutoMod to use the default AutoMod level instead of using the individual settings.
Valid values for all levels are from 0 (no filtering) through 4 (most aggressive filtering). These levels affect how aggressively AutoMod holds back messages for moderators to review before they appear in chat or are denied (not shown).

examples.comment: This example updates the `overall_level` setting to 3.Notice in the response that not all settings are set to level 3.If `overall_level` is set to 3 and you try to change `swearing` to 2, all other settings are set to 0. If the goal was to change the `swearing` setting and leave all the others unchanged, the request must have included all the other settings as well.

Get Banned Users.short: Gets all users that the broadcaster banned or put in a timeout.
Get Banned Users.long: Gets all users that the broadcaster banned or put in a timeout.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose list of banned users you want to get. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

user_id.description: A list of user IDs used to filter the results. To specify more than one ID, include this parameter for each user you want to get. For example, `user_id=1234&user_id=5678`. You may specify a maximum of 100 IDs.The returned list includes only those users that were banned or put in a timeout. The list is returned in the same order that you specified the IDs.

first.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

after.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

before.description: The cursor used to get the previous page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

data.description: The list of users that were banned or put in a timeout.

user_id.description: The ID of the banned user.

expires_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the timeout expires, or an empty string if the user is permanently banned.

created_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the user was banned.

reason.description: The reason the user was banned or put in a timeout if the moderator provided one.

moderator_id.description: The ID of the moderator that banned the user or put them in a timeout.

pagination.description: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

cursor.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of banned users.
codes.400: - The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
codes.401:
- The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderation:read scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

Get Banned Users.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderation:read`, `moderator:manage:banned_users`

Ban User.short: Bans a user from participating in a broadcaster’s chat room or puts them in a timeout.
Ban User.long:
Bans a user from participating in the specified broadcaster’s chat room or puts them in a timeout.
For information about banning or putting users in a timeout, see [Ban a User](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/how-to-manage-harassment-in-chat#TheBanFeature) and [Timeout a User](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/how-to-manage-harassment-in-chat#TheTimeoutFeature).
If the user is currently in a timeout, you can call this endpoint to change the duration of the timeout or ban them altogether. If the user is currently banned, you cannot call this method to put them in a timeout instead.
To remove a ban or end a timeout, see [Unban user](#unban-user).

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose chat room the user is being banned from.

moderator_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster or a user that has permission to moderate the broadcaster’s chat room. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

data.description: Identifies the user and type of ban.

user_id.description: The ID of the user to ban or put in a timeout.

duration.description: To ban a user indefinitely, don’t include this field.To put a user in a timeout, include this field and specify the timeout period, in seconds. The minimum timeout is 1 second and the maximum is 1,209,600 seconds (2 weeks).To end a user’s timeout early, set this field to 1, or use the [Unban user](#unban-user) endpoint.

reason.description: The reason the you’re banning the user or putting them in a timeout. The text is user defined and is limited to a maximum of 500 characters.

data.description: A list that contains the user you successfully banned or put in a timeout.

broadcaster_id.description: The broadcaster whose chat room the user was banned from chatting in.

moderator_id.description: The moderator that banned or put the user in the timeout.

user_id.description: The user that was banned or put in a timeout.

created_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) that the ban or timeout was placed.

end_time.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) that the timeout will end. Is *null* if the user was banned instead of being put in a timeout.

codes.200: Successfully banned the user or placed them in a timeout.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The moderator_id query parameter is required.
- The `user_id` field is required.
- The text in the `reason` field is too long.
- The value in the `duration` field is not valid.
- The user specified in the `user_id` field may not be banned.
- The user specified in the `user_id` field may not be put in a timeout.
- The user specified in the `user_id` field is already banned.
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:manage:banned_users scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: - The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.
codes.409: - You may not update the user's ban state while someone else is updating the state. For example, someone else is currently banning the user or putting them in a timeout, moving the user from a timeout to a ban, or removing the user from a ban or timeout. Please retry your request.
codes.429: - The app has exceeded the number of requests it may make per minute for this broadcaster.

Ban User.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:manage:banned_users`

examples.comment: Bans a user (it doesn’t include the `duration` field).Puts a user in a 5-minute timeout.Shows what happens if you try to place a banned user in a timeout. You can ban a user that’s already in a timeout but you can’t move a banned user into a timeout. To do this, you’d have to remove the ban and then place them in a timeout.You’ll get the same response if you try to ban a user who is already banned.

Unban User.short: Removes the ban or timeout that was placed on the specified user.

To ban a user, see [Ban user](#ban-user).

codes.400:

codes.403: - The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.
codes.409: - You may not update the user's ban state while someone else is updating the state. For example, someone else is currently removing the ban or timeout, or they're moving the user from a timeout to a ban. Please retry your request.
codes.429: - The app has exceeded the number of requests it may make per minute for this broadcaster.

Get Unban Requests.long: Gets a list of unban requests for a broadcaster’s channel.

status.description:
Status of the request. One of:

  }
}

Resolve Unban Requests.short: Resolves an unban request by approving or denying it.
Resolve Unban Requests.long: Resolves an unban request by approving or denying it.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose channel is approving or denying the unban request.

moderator_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster or a user that has permission to moderate the broadcaster’s unban requests. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

unban_request_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster or a user that has permission to moderate the broadcaster’s unban requests. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

status.description:
Resolution status. - approved
- denied

resolution_text.description: Message supplied by the unban request resolver. The message is limited to a maximum of 500 characters.

id.description: Unban request ID.

broadcaster_id.description: User ID of broadcaster whose channel is receiving the unban request.

moderator_id.description: User ID of moderator who approved/denied the request.

user_id.description: User ID of the requestor who is asking for an unban.

text.description: Text of the request from the requesting user.

status.description:
Status of the request. One of: - approved
- denied

created_at.description: Timestamp of when the unban request was created.

resolved_at.description: Timestamp of when moderator/broadcaster approved or denied the request.

resolution_text.description: Text input by the resolver (moderator) of the unban request.

codes.200: Successfully resolved the unban request.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
- The moderator_id query parameter is required.
- The ID in the moderator_id query parameter is not valid.
- The pagination cursor is not valid.
- The broadcaster is not receiving unban requests
- Invalid requested update
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:manage:unban_requests scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.404: The unban request ID was not found.

Resolve Unban Requests.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:manage:unban_requests`

examples.comment: Approving an unban request.

Get Blocked Terms.short: Gets the broadcaster’s list of non-private, blocked words or phrases.
Get Blocked Terms.long: Gets the broadcaster’s list of non-private, blocked words or phrases. These are the terms that the broadcaster or moderator added manually or that were denied by AutoMod.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose blocked terms you’re getting.

moderator_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster or a user that has permission to moderate the broadcaster’s chat room. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

first.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

after.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value.

data.description: The list of blocked terms. The list is in descending order of when they were created (see the `created_at` timestamp).

broadcaster_id.description: The broadcaster that owns the list of blocked terms.

moderator_id.description: The moderator that blocked the word or phrase from being used in the broadcaster’s chat room.

id.description: An ID that identifies this blocked term.

created_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) that the term was blocked.

updated_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) that the term was updated.When the term is added, this timestamp is the same as `created_at`. The timestamp changes as AutoMod continues to deny the term.

expires_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) that the blocked term is set to expire. After the block expires, users may use the term in the broadcaster’s chat room.This field is *null* if the term was added manually or was permanently blocked by AutoMod.

pagination.description: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

cursor.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of blocked terms.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The moderator_id query parameter is required.
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:read:blocked_terms scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: - The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.

Get Blocked Terms.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:read:blocked_terms`, `moderator:manage:blocked_terms`

examples.comment: Gets the last 10 blocked terms (see the first query parameter) that were added.

Add Blocked Term.short: Adds a word or phrase to the broadcaster’s list of blocked terms.
Add Blocked Term.long: Adds a word or phrase to the broadcaster’s list of blocked terms. These are the terms that the broadcaster doesn’t want used in their chat room.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the list of blocked terms.

moderator_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster or a user that has permission to moderate the broadcaster’s chat room. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

text.description: The word or phrase to block from being used in the broadcaster’s chat room. The term must contain a minimum of 2 characters and may contain up to a maximum of 500 characters.Terms may include a wildcard character (*). The wildcard character must appear at the beginning or end of a word or set of characters. For example, *foo or foo*.If the blocked term already exists, the response contains the existing blocked term.

data.description: A list that contains the single blocked term that the broadcaster added.

broadcaster_id.description: The broadcaster that owns the list of blocked terms.

moderator_id.description: The moderator that blocked the word or phrase from being used in the broadcaster’s chat room.

id.description: An ID that identifies this blocked term.

created_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) that the term was blocked.

updated_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) that the term was updated.When the term is added, this timestamp is the same as `created_at`. The timestamp changes as AutoMod continues to deny the term.

expires_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) that the blocked term is set to expire. After the block expires, users may use the term in the broadcaster’s chat room.This field is *null* if the term was added manually or was permanently blocked by AutoMod.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of blocked terms.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The moderator_id query parameter is required.
- The `text` field is required.
- The length of the term in the `text` field is either too short or too long.
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:manage:blocked_terms scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: - The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.

Add Blocked Term.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:manage:blocked_terms`

examples.comment: Adds a blocked term. Adding the same term again will return the previously added term.Adds a term that uses the wildcard character (*).

Remove Blocked Term.short: Removes the word or phrase from the broadcaster’s list of blocked terms.
Remove Blocked Term.long: Removes the word or phrase from the broadcaster’s list of blocked terms.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the list of blocked terms.

moderator_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster or a user that has permission to moderate the broadcaster’s chat room. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

id.description: The ID of the blocked term to remove from the broadcaster’s list of blocked terms.

codes.204: Successfully removed the blocked term. Also returned if the ID is not found.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The moderator_id query parameter is required.
- The id query parameter is required.
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:manage:blocked_terms scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: - The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.

Remove Blocked Term.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:manage:blocked_terms`

examples.comment: Deletes the specified blocked term.

Delete Chat Messages.short: Removes a single chat message or all chat messages from the broadcaster’s chat room.
Delete Chat Messages.long: Removes a single chat message or all chat messages from the broadcaster’s chat room.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the chat room to remove messages from.

moderator_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster or a user that has permission to moderate the broadcaster’s chat room. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

message_id.description:
The ID of the message to remove. The `id` tag in the [PRIVMSG](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/irc/tags#privmsg-tags) tag contains the message’s ID. Restrictions:
- The message must have been created within the last 6 hours.
- The message must not belong to the broadcaster.
- The message must not belong to another moderator.
If not specified, the request removes all messages in the broadcaster’s chat room.
possible: ags) tag contains the message’s ID. Restrictions:
The message must have been created within the last 6 hours.
The message must not belong to the broadcaster.
The message must not belong to another moderator.

codes.400:
- You may not delete another moderator's messages.
- You may not delete the broadcaster's messages.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token is missing the moderator:manage:chat_messages scope.
- The OAuth token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the OAuth token.
codes.403: - The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.
codes.404:
- The ID in message_id was not found.
- The specified message was created more than 6 hours ago.

Delete Chat Messages.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:manage:chat_messages`

examples.comment: Removes all messages from the broadcaster’s chat room (doesn’t include the message_id query parameter).Removes the specified message from the broadcaster’s chat room.

Get Moderated Channels.short: Gets a list of channels that the specified user has moderator privileges in.
Get Moderated Channels.long: Gets a list of channels that the specified user has moderator privileges in.

user_id.description: A user’s ID. Returns the list of channels that this user has moderator privileges in. This ID must match the user ID in the user OAuth token

after.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value.

first.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response.Minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100. The default is 20.

data.description: The list of channels that the user has moderator privileges in.

broadcaster_id.description: An ID that uniquely identifies the channel this user can moderate.

pagination.description: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through.

cursor.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

Get Moderated Channels.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `user:read:moderated_channels`

Get Moderators.short: Gets all users allowed to moderate the broadcaster’s chat room.
Get Moderators.long: Gets all users allowed to moderate the broadcaster’s chat room.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose list of moderators you want to get. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

user_id.description: A list of user IDs used to filter the results. To specify more than one ID, include this parameter for each moderator you want to get. For example, `user_id=1234&user_id=5678`. You may specify a maximum of 100 IDs.The returned list includes only the users from the list who are moderators in the broadcaster’s channel. The list is returned in the same order as you specified the IDs.

first.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

after.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

data.description: The list of moderators.

user_id.description: The ID of the user that has permission to moderate the broadcaster’s channel.

pagination.description: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

cursor.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of moderators.
codes.400: - The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
codes.401:
- The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID found in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderation:read scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

Get Moderators.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderation:read`, `channel:manage:moderators`

Add Channel Moderator.short: Adds a moderator to the broadcaster’s chat room.
Add Channel Moderator.long:
Adds a moderator to the broadcaster’s chat room.
*Rate Limits*: The broadcaster may add a maximum of 10 moderators within a 10-second window.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the chat room. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

user_id.description: The ID of the user to add as a moderator in the broadcaster’s chat room.

codes.400:

- The ID in user_id was not found.
- The user in user_id is already a moderator in the broadcaster's chat room.
- The user in user_id cannot become a moderator because they're banned from the channel.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:manage:moderators scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.422: - The user in user_id is a VIP. To make them a moderator, you must first remove them as a VIP (see [Remove Channel VIP](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/reference#remove-channel-vip)).
codes.429: - The broadcaster has exceeded the number of requests allowed within a 10-second window. See this endpoint's rate limits.

Add Channel Moderator.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `channel:manage:moderators`

Remove Channel Moderator.short: Removes a moderator from the broadcaster’s chat room.
Remove Channel Moderator.long:
Removes a moderator from the broadcaster’s chat room.
*Rate Limits*: The broadcaster may remove a maximum of 10 moderators within a 10-second window.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the chat room. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

user_id.description: The ID of the user to remove as a moderator from the broadcaster’s chat room.

codes.400:
- The ID in broadcaster_id was not found.
- The ID in user_id was not found.
- The user in user_id is not a moderator in the broadcaster's chat room.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:manage:moderators scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.429: - The broadcaster has exceeded the number of requests allowed within a 10-second window. See this endpoint's rate limits.

Remove Channel Moderator.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `channel:manage:moderators`

Get VIPs.short: Gets a list of the broadcaster’s VIPs.
Get VIPs.long: Gets a list of the broadcaster’s VIPs.

user_id.description: Filters the list for specific VIPs. To specify more than one user, include the user_id parameter for each user to get. For example, `&user_id=1234&user_id=5678`. The maximum number of IDs that you may specify is 100. Ignores the ID of those users in the list that aren’t VIPs.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose list of VIPs you want to get. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

first.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100. The default is 20.

after.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

data.description: The list of VIPs. The list is empty if the broadcaster doesn’t have VIP users.

user_id.description: An ID that uniquely identifies the VIP user.

pagination.description: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

cursor.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s list of VIPs.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The ID in the user_id query parameter is not valid.
- The number of user_id query parameters exceeds the maximum allowed.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:read:vips or channel:manage:vips scope.
- The OAuth token is not valid.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the OAuth token.

Get VIPs.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `channel:read:vips`, `channel:manage:vips`

examples.comment: Gets a list of the broadcaster’s VIPsGets a filtered list of the broadcaster’s VIPs. The list in the response contains only those users that are VIPs.

Add Channel VIP.short: Adds the specified user as a VIP in the broadcaster’s channel.
Add Channel VIP.long:
Adds the specified user as a VIP in the broadcaster’s channel.
*Rate Limits*: The broadcaster may add a maximum of 10 VIPs within a 10-second window.

user_id.description: The ID of the user to give VIP status to.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster that’s adding the user as a VIP. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

Add Channel VIP.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `channel:manage:vips`

examples.comment: Adds a VIP to the broadcaster’s chat room.

Remove Channel VIP.short: Removes the specified user as a VIP in the broadcaster’s channel.
Remove Channel VIP.long:
Removes the specified user as a VIP in the broadcaster’s channel.
If the broadcaster is removing the user’s VIP status, the ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token; otherwise, if the user is removing their VIP status themselves, the ID in the user_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token.
*Rate Limits*: The broadcaster may remove a maximum of 10 VIPs within a 10-second window.

user_id.description: The ID of the user to remove VIP status from.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster who owns the channel where the user has VIP status.

Remove Channel VIP.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `channel:manage:vips`

examples.comment: Removes the VIP user from the broadcaster’s channel.

Update Shield Mode Status.short: Activates or deactivates the broadcaster’s Shield Mode.
Update Shield Mode Status.long:
Activates or deactivates the broadcaster’s Shield Mode.
Twitch’s Shield Mode feature is like a panic button that broadcasters can push to protect themselves from chat abuse coming from one or more accounts. When activated, Shield Mode applies the overrides that the broadcaster configured in the Twitch UX. If the broadcaster hasn’t configured Shield Mode, it applies default overrides.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose Shield Mode you want to activate or deactivate.

moderator_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster or a user that is one of the broadcaster’s moderators. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

is_active.description: A Boolean value that determines whether to activate Shield Mode. Set to *true* to activate Shield Mode; otherwise, *false* to deactivate Shield Mode.

data.description: A list that contains a single object with the broadcaster’s updated Shield Mode status.

is_active.description: A Boolean value that determines whether Shield Mode is active. Is *true* if Shield Mode is active; otherwise, *false*.

moderator_id.description: An ID that identifies the moderator that last activated Shield Mode.

last_activated_at.description: The UTC timestamp (in RFC3339 format) of when Shield Mode was last activated.

codes.200: Successfully updated the broadcaster’s Shield Mode status.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
- The `is_active` field is required.
- The value in the `is_active` field is not valid.
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:manage:shield_mode scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: - The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.

Update Shield Mode Status.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:manage:shield_mode`

examples.request:
curl -X PUT 'https://api.twitch.tv/helix/moderation/shield_mode?broadcaster_id=12345&moderator_id=98765' \
-H 'Authorization: Bearer kpvy3cjboypmiacwr0c19hotn5s' \
-H 'Client-Id: hof5gwx0su6owfn0yan9c87zr6t' \
-H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
-d '{"is_active":false}'

Get Shield Mode Status.short: Gets the broadcaster’s Shield Mode activation status.
Get Shield Mode Status.long:
Gets the broadcaster’s Shield Mode activation status.
To receive notification when the broadcaster activates and deactivates Shield Mode, subscribe to the [channel.shield_mode.begin](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/eventsub/eventsub-subscription-types#channelshield_modebegin) and [channel.shield_mode.end](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/eventsub/eventsub-subscription-types#channelshield_modeend) subscription types.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose Shield Mode activation status you want to get.

moderator_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster or a user that is one of the broadcaster’s moderators. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

data.description: A list that contains a single object with the broadcaster’s Shield Mode status.

is_active.description: A Boolean value that determines whether Shield Mode is active. Is *true* if the broadcaster activated Shield Mode; otherwise, *false*.

moderator_id.description: An ID that identifies the moderator that last activated Shield Mode. Is an empty string if Shield Mode hasn’t been previously activated.

moderator_login.description: The moderator’s login name. Is an empty string if Shield Mode hasn’t been previously activated.

moderator_name.description: The moderator’s display name. Is an empty string if Shield Mode hasn’t been previously activated.

last_activated_at.description: The UTC timestamp (in RFC3339 format) of when Shield Mode was last activated. Is an empty string if Shield Mode hasn’t been previously activated.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s Shield Mode activation status.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:read:shield_mode or moderator:manage:shield_mode scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: - The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.

Get Shield Mode Status.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:read:shield_mode`, `moderator:manage:shield_mode`

Warn Chat User.short: Warns a user in the specified broadcaster’s chat room, preventing them from chat interaction until the warning is acknowledged.
Warn Chat User.long: Warns a user in the specified broadcaster’s chat room, preventing them from chat interaction until the warning is acknowledged. New warnings can be issued to a user when they already have a warning in the channel (new warning will replace old warning).

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the channel in which the warning will take effect.

moderator_id.description: The ID of the twitch user who requested the warning.

data.description: A list that contains information about the warning.

user_id.description: The ID of the twitch user to be warned.

reason.description: A custom reason for the warning. *Max 500 chars.*

data.description: A list that contains information about the warning.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the channel in which the warning will take effect.

user_id.description: The ID of the warned user.

moderator_id.description: The ID of the user who applied the warning.

codes.200: Successfully warn a user.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The moderator_id query parameter is required.
- The user_id query parameter is required.
- The reason query parameter is required.
- The text in the reason field is too long.
- The user specified in the user_id may not be warned.
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:manage:warnings scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster’s moderators.
codes.409: You may not update the user’s warning state while someone else is updating the state. For example, someone else is currently warning the user or the user is acknowledging an existing warning. Please retry your request.
codes.429: The app has exceeded the number of requests it may make per minute for this broadcaster.

Warn Chat User.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:manage:warnings`

examples.request:

Add Suspicious Status to Chat User.long: NEW Adds a suspicious user status to a chatter on the broadcaster’s channel.

broadcaster_id.description: The user ID of the broadcaster, indicating the channel where the status is being applied.

Remove Suspicious Status From Chat User.short: NEW Remove a suspicious user status from a chatter on broadcaster’s channel.
Remove Suspicious Status From Chat User.long: NEW Remove a suspicious user status from a chatter on broadcaster’s channel.

broadcaster_id.description: The user ID of the broadcaster, indicating the channel where the status is being removed.

moderator_id.description: The user ID of the moderator who is removing the status.

user_id.description: The ID of the user having the suspicious status removed.

data.description: An array with one object containing information about the suspicious user action.

user_id.description: The ID of the user having the suspicious status removed.

broadcaster_id.description: The user ID of the broadcaster indicating in which channel the status is being removed.

moderator_id.description: The user ID of the moderator who modified the last status.

updated_at.description: The timestamp of the last time this user’s status was updated.

status.description: The type of suspicious status. Possible values are: NO_TREATMENT

types.description: An array of strings representing the type(s) of suspicious user this is. Possible values are: MANUALLY_ADDED, DETECTED_BAN_EVADER, DETECTED_SUS_CHATTER, BANNED_IN_SHARED_CHANNEL

codes.200: Successfully removed a suspicious user status.
codes.400:
- Validation errors: Missing required fields.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter was not found.
- The status update is not allowed for this user.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must specify user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:manage:suspicious_users scope.
- The OAuth token is not valid.
- The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.
codes.403: - The user in the moderator_id query parameter is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.

Remove Suspicious Status From Chat User.auth: Requires an [app access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#app-access-tokens) or a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `moderator:manage:suspicious_users`

examples.comment: Removes a suspicious user status from a user.

Get Polls.short: Gets a list of polls that the broadcaster created.
Get Polls.long:
Gets a list of polls that the broadcaster created.
Polls are available for 90 days after they’re created.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster that created the polls. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

id.description: A list of IDs that identify the polls to return. To specify more than one ID, include this parameter for each poll you want to get. For example, `id=1234&id=5678`. You may specify a maximum of 20 IDs.Specify this parameter only if you want to filter the list that the request returns. The endpoint ignores duplicate IDs and those not owned by this broadcaster.

first.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 20 items per page. The default is 20.

after.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

data.description: A list of polls. The polls are returned in descending order of start time unless you specify IDs in the request, in which case they're returned in the same order as you passed them in the request. The list is empty if the broadcaster hasn't created polls.

id.description: An ID that identifies the poll.

broadcaster_id.description: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that created the poll.

title.description: The question that viewers are voting on. For example, What game should I play next? The title may contain a maximum of 60 characters.

choices.description: A list of choices that viewers can choose from. The list will contain a minimum of two choices and up to a maximum of five choices.

id.description: An ID that identifies this choice.

title.description: The choice's title. The title may contain a maximum of 25 characters.

votes.description: The total number of votes cast for this choice.

channel_points_votes.description: The number of votes cast using Channel Points.

bits_votes.description: Not used; will be set to 0.

bits_voting_enabled.description: Not used; will be set to *false*.

bits_per_vote.description: Not used; will be set to 0.

channel_points_voting_enabled.description: A Boolean value that indicates whether viewers may cast additional votes using Channel Points. For information about Channel Points, see [Channel Points Guide](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/channel-points-guide).

channel_points_per_vote.description: The number of points the viewer must spend to cast one additional vote.

status.description:
The poll's status. Valid values are:
- ACTIVE — The poll is running.
- COMPLETED — The poll ended on schedule (see the `duration` field).
- TERMINATED — The poll was terminated before its scheduled end.
- ARCHIVED — The poll has been archived and is no longer visible on the channel.
- MODERATED — The poll was deleted.
- INVALID — Something went wrong while determining the state.

duration.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the poll will run for.

started_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the poll began.

ended_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the poll ended. If `status` is ACTIVE, this field is set to *null*.

pagination.description: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

cursor.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request's after query parameter.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster's polls.
codes.400: - The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
codes.401:
- The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token is missing the channel:read:polls scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header must match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.404: - None of the IDs in the id query parameters were found.

Get Polls.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `channel:read:polls`, `channel:manage:polls`

examples.comment: Gets the specified broadcaster’s list of polls.

Create Poll.short: Creates a poll that viewers in the broadcaster’s channel can vote on.
Create Poll.long:
Creates a poll that viewers in the broadcaster’s channel can vote on.
The poll begins as soon as it’s created. You may run only one poll at a time.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster that’s running the poll. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

title.description: The question that viewers will vote on. For example, What game should I play next? The question may contain a maximum of 60 characters.

choices.description: A list of choices that viewers may choose from. The list must contain a minimum of 2 choices and up to a maximum of 5 choices.

title.description: One of the choices the viewer may select. The choice may contain a maximum of 25 characters.

duration.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the poll will run for. The minimum is 15 seconds and the maximum is 1800 seconds (30 minutes).

channel_points_voting_enabled.description: A Boolean value that indicates whether viewers may cast additional votes using Channel Points. If *true*, the viewer may cast more than one vote but each additional vote costs the number of Channel Points specified in `channel_points_per_vote`. The default is *false* (viewers may cast only one vote). For information about Channel Points, see [Channel Points Guide](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/channel-points-guide).

channel_points_per_vote.description: The number of points that the viewer must spend to cast one additional vote. The minimum is 1 and the maximum is 1000000. Set only if `ChannelPointsVotingEnabled` is *true*.

data.description: A list that contains the single poll that you created.

id.description: An ID that identifies the poll.

broadcaster_id.description: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that created the poll.

title.description: The question that viewers are voting on. For example, What game should I play next? The title may contain a maximum of 60 characters.

choices.description: A list of choices that viewers can choose from. The list will contain a minimum of two choices and up to a maximum of five choices.

id.description: An ID that identifies this choice.

title.description: The choice’s title. The title may contain a maximum of 25 characters.

votes.description: The total number of votes cast for this choice.

channel_points_votes.description: The number of votes cast using Channel Points.

bits_votes.description: Not used; will be set to 0.

bits_voting_enabled.description: Not used; will be set to *false*.

bits_per_vote.description: Not used; will be set to 0.

channel_points_voting_enabled.description: A Boolean value that indicates whether viewers may cast additional votes using Channel Points. For information about Channel Points, see [Channel Points Guide](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/channel-points-guide).

channel_points_per_vote.description: The number of points the viewer must spend to cast one additional vote.

status.description:
The poll’s status. Valid values are:
- ACTIVE — The poll is running.
- COMPLETED — The poll ended on schedule (see the `duration` field).
- TERMINATED — The poll was terminated before its scheduled end.
- ARCHIVED — The poll has been archived and is no longer visible on the channel.
- MODERATED — The poll was deleted.
- INVALID — Something went wrong while determining the state.

duration.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the poll will run for.

started_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the poll began.

ended_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the poll ended. If `status` is ACTIVE, this field is set to *null*.

codes.200: Successfully created the poll.
codes.400:
- The `broadcaster_id` field is required.
- The `title` field is required.
- The `choices` field is required.
- The `duration` field is required.
- The value in `duration` is outside the allowed range of values.
- The value in `channel_points_per_vote` is outside the allowed range of values.
- The value in `bits_per_vote` is outside the allowed range of values.
- The poll's `title` is too long.
- The choice's `title` is too long.
- The choice's `title` failed AutoMod checks.
- The number of choices in the poll may not be less than 2 or greater that 5.
- The broadcaster already has a poll that's running; you may not create another poll until the current poll completes.
codes.401:
- The ID in `broadcaster_id` must match the user ID in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token is missing the channel:manage:polls scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

Create Poll.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `channel:manage:polls`

examples.comment: Creates a poll for the specified broadcaster.

End Poll.long: Ends an active poll. You have the option to end it or end it and archive it.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster that’s running the poll. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

id.description: The ID of the poll to update.

status.description:
The status to set the poll to. Possible case-sensitive values are:
- TERMINATED — Ends the poll before the poll is scheduled to end. The poll remains publicly visible.
- ARCHIVED — Ends the poll before the poll is scheduled to end, and then archives it so it's no longer publicly visible.

data.description: A list that contains the poll that you ended.

id.description: An ID that identifies the poll.

broadcaster_id.description: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that created the poll.

title.description: The question that viewers are voting on. For example, What game should I play next? The title may contain a maximum of 60 characters.

choices.description: A list of choices that viewers can choose from. The list will contain a minimum of two choices and up to a maximum of five choices.

id.description: An ID that identifies this choice.

title.description: The choice’s title. The title may contain a maximum of 25 characters.

votes.description: The total number of votes cast for this choice.

channel_points_votes.description: The number of votes cast using Channel Points.

bits_votes.description: Not used; will be set to 0.

bits_voting_enabled.description: Not used; will be set to *false*.

bits_per_vote.description: Not used; will be set to 0.

channel_points_voting_enabled.description: A Boolean value that indicates whether viewers may cast additional votes using Channel Points. For information about Channel Points, see [Channel Points Guide](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/channel-points-guide).

channel_points_per_vote.description: The number of points the viewer must spend to cast one additional vote.

status.description:
The poll’s status. Valid values are:
- ACTIVE — The poll is running.
- COMPLETED — The poll ended on schedule (see the `duration` field).
- TERMINATED — The poll was terminated before its scheduled end.
- ARCHIVED — The poll has been archived and is no longer visible on the channel.
- MODERATED — The poll was deleted.
- INVALID — Something went wrong while determining the state.

duration.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the poll will run for.

started_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the poll began.

ended_at.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the poll ended. If `status` is ACTIVE, this field is set to *null*.

codes.200: Successfully ended the poll.
codes.400:
- The `broadcaster_id` field is required.
- The `id` field is required.
- The `status` field is required.
- The value in the `status` field is not valid.
- The poll must be active to terminate or archive it.
codes.401:
- The ID in `broadcaster_id` must match the user ID in the user access token.

- The user access token must include the channel:manage:polls scope.

Get Predictions.short: Gets a list of Channel Points Predictions that the broadcaster created.
Get Predictions.long: Gets a list of Channel Points Predictions that the broadcaster created.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose predictions you want to get. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

id.description: The ID of the prediction to get. To specify more than one ID, include this parameter for each prediction you want to get. For example, `id=1234&id=5678`. You may specify a maximum of 25 IDs. The endpoint ignores duplicate IDs and those not owned by the broadcaster.

first.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 25 items per page. The default is 20.

after.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

data.description: The broadcaster’s list of Channel Points Predictions. The list is sorted in descending ordered by when the prediction began (the most recent prediction is first). The list is empty if the broadcaster hasn’t created predictions.

id.description: An ID that identifies this prediction.

broadcaster_id.description: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that created the prediction.

title.description: The question that the prediction asks. For example, Will I finish this entire pizza?

winning_outcome_id.description: The ID of the winning outcome. Is *null* unless `status` is RESOLVED.

outcomes.description: The list of possible outcomes for the prediction.

id.description: An ID that identifies this outcome.

title.description: The outcome’s text.

users.description: The number of unique viewers that chose this outcome.

channel_points.description: The number of Channel Points spent by viewers on this outcome.

top_predictors.description: A list of viewers who were the top predictors; otherwise, *null* if none.

user_id.description: An ID that identifies the viewer.

channel_points_used.description: The number of Channel Points the viewer spent.

channel_points_won.description: The number of Channel Points distributed to the viewer.

color.description:
The color that visually identifies this outcome in the UX. Possible values are:
- BLUE
- PINK
If the number of outcomes is two, the color is BLUE for the first outcome and PINK for the second outcome. If there are more than two outcomes, the color is BLUE for all outcomes.

prediction_window.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the prediction will run for.

status.description:
The prediction’s status. Valid values are:
- ACTIVE — The Prediction is running and viewers can make predictions.
- CANCELED — The broadcaster canceled the Prediction and refunded the Channel Points to the participants.
- LOCKED — The broadcaster locked the Prediction, which means viewers can no longer make predictions.
- RESOLVED — The winning outcome was determined and the Channel Points were distributed to the viewers who predicted the correct outcome.

created_at.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction began.

ended_at.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction ended. If `status` is ACTIVE, this is set to *null*.

locked_at.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction was locked. If `status` is not LOCKED, this is set to *null*.

pagination.description: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

cursor.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of predictions.
codes.400: - The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
codes.401:
- The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:read:predictions scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

Get Predictions.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `channel:read:predictions`, `channel:manage:predictions`

examples.comment: Gets the specified broadcaster’s list of predictions.

Create Prediction.long:
Creates a Channel Points Prediction.
With a Channel Points Prediction, the broadcaster poses a question and viewers try to predict the outcome. The prediction runs as soon as it’s created. The broadcaster may run only one prediction at a time.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster that’s running the prediction. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

title.description: The question that the broadcaster is asking. For example, Will I finish this entire pizza? The title is limited to a maximum of 45 characters.

outcomes.description: The list of possible outcomes that the viewers may choose from. The list must contain a minimum of 2 choices and up to a maximum of 10 choices.

title.description: The text of one of the outcomes that the viewer may select. The title is limited to a maximum of 25 characters.

prediction_window.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the prediction will run for. The minimum is 30 seconds and the maximum is 1800 seconds (30 minutes).

data.description: A list that contains the single prediction that you created.

id.description: An ID that identifies this prediction.

broadcaster_id.description: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that created the prediction.

title.description: The question that the prediction asks. For example, Will I finish this entire pizza?

winning_outcome_id.description: The ID of the winning outcome. Is *null* unless `status` is RESOLVED.

outcomes.description: The list of possible outcomes for the prediction.

id.description: An ID that identifies this outcome.

title.description: The outcome’s text.

users.description: The number of unique viewers that chose this outcome.

channel_points.description: The number of Channel Points spent by viewers on this outcome.

top_predictors.description: A list of viewers who were the top predictors; otherwise, *null* if none.

user_id.description: An ID that identifies the viewer.

channel_points_used.description: The number of Channel Points the viewer spent.

channel_points_won.description: The number of Channel Points distributed to the viewer.

color.description:
The color that visually identifies this outcome in the UX. Possible values are:
- BLUE
- PINK
If the number of outcomes is two, the color is BLUE for the first outcome and PINK for the second outcome. If there are more than two outcomes, the color is BLUE for all outcomes.

prediction_window.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the prediction will run for.

status.description:
The prediction’s status. Valid values are:
- ACTIVE — The Prediction is running and viewers can make predictions.
- CANCELED — The broadcaster canceled the Prediction and refunded the Channel Points to the participants.
- LOCKED — The broadcaster locked the Prediction, which means viewers can no longer make predictions.
- RESOLVED — The winning outcome was determined and the Channel Points were distributed to the viewers who predicted the correct outcome.

created_at.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction began.

ended_at.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction ended. If `status` is ACTIVE, this is set to *null*.

locked_at.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction was locked. If `status` is not LOCKED, this is set to *null*.

codes.200: Successfully created the Channel Points Prediction.
codes.400:
- The `broadcaster_id` field is required.
- The `title` field is required.
- The `outcomes` field is required.
- The `prediction_window` field is required.
- The value in `prediction_window` is outside the allowed range of values.
- The prediction's `title` is too long.
- The outcome's `title` is too long.
- The outcome's `title` failed AutoMod checks.
- There must be 2 outcomes in the prediction.
- The broadcaster already has a prediction that's running; you may not create another prediction until the current prediction is resolved or canceled.
codes.401:
- The ID in `broadcaster_id` must match the user ID in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:manage:predictions scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

Create Prediction.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `channel:manage:predictions`

examples.comment: Creates a Channel Points Prediction for the specified broadcaster.

End Prediction.short: Locks, resolves, or cancels a Channel Points Prediction.
End Prediction.long: Locks, resolves, or cancels a Channel Points Prediction.

broadcaster_id.description: The ID of the broadcaster that’s running the prediction. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

id.description: The ID of the prediction to update.

status.description:
The status to set the prediction to. Possible case-sensitive values are:
- RESOLVED — The winning outcome is determined and the Channel Points are distributed to the viewers who predicted the correct outcome.
- CANCELED — The broadcaster is canceling the prediction and sending refunds to the participants.
- LOCKED — The broadcaster is locking the prediction, which means viewers may no longer make predictions.
The broadcaster can update an active prediction to LOCKED, RESOLVED, or CANCELED; and update a locked prediction to RESOLVED or CANCELED.The broadcaster has up to 24 hours after the prediction window closes to resolve the prediction. If not, Twitch sets the status to CANCELED and returns the points.

winning_outcome_id.description: The ID of the winning outcome. You must set this parameter if you set `status` to RESOLVED.

data.description: A list that contains the single prediction that you updated.

id.description: An ID that identifies this prediction.

broadcaster_id.description: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that created the prediction.

title.description: The question that the prediction asks. For example, Will I finish this entire pizza?

winning_outcome_id.description: The ID of the winning outcome. Is *null* unless `status` is RESOLVED.

outcomes.description: The list of possible outcomes for the prediction.

id.description: An ID that identifies this outcome.

title.description: The outcome’s text.

users.description: The number of unique viewers that chose this outcome.

channel_points.description: The number of Channel Points spent by viewers on this outcome.

top_predictors.description: A list of viewers who were the top predictors; otherwise, *null* if none.

user_id.description: An ID that identifies the viewer.

channel_points_used.description: The number of Channel Points the viewer spent.

channel_points_won.description: The number of Channel Points distributed to the viewer.

color.description:
The color that visually identifies this outcome in the UX. Possible values are:
- BLUE
- PINK
If the number of outcomes is two, the color is BLUE for the first outcome and PINK for the second outcome. If there are more than two outcomes, the color is BLUE for all outcomes.

prediction_window.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the prediction will run for.

status.description:
The prediction’s status. Valid values are:
- ACTIVE — The Prediction is running and viewers can make predictions.
- CANCELED — The broadcaster canceled the Prediction and refunded the Channel Points to the participants.
- LOCKED — The broadcaster locked the Prediction, which means viewers can no longer make predictions.
- RESOLVED — The winning outcome was determined and the Channel Points were distributed to the viewers who predicted the correct outcome.

created_at.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction began.

ended_at.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction ended. If `status` is ACTIVE, this is set to *null*.

locked_at.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction was locked. If `status` is not LOCKED, this is set to *null*.

codes.200: Successfully ended the prediction.
codes.400:
- The `broadcaster_id` field is required.
- The `id` field is required.
- The `status` field is required.
- The `winning_outcome_id` field is required if `status` is RESOLVED.
- The value in the `status` field is not valid.
- To update the prediction's status to RESOLVED or CANCELED, its current status must be ACTIVE or LOCKED.
- To update the prediction's status to LOCKED, its current status must be ACTIVE.
codes.401:
- The ID in `broadcaster_id` must match the user ID in the OAuth token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:manage:predictions scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.404:
- The prediction in the `id` field was not found.
- The outcome in the `winning_outcome_id` field was not found.

End Prediction.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens)) with any of the following scopes: `channel:manage:predictions`
